title: RL33399
content: The Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies are funded by P.L. 110-5, the Revised Continuing Appropriations Resolution for FY2007. The law maintains funds at the FY2006 account level, with agencies required to submit fund allocations within 30 days of enactment. This bill covers agencies in the Department of the Interior, Forest Service, and other related departments and bureaus. The bill provides funds for agencies in the Department of Agriculture, Department of Health and Human Services, and Environmental Protection Agency. It also includes funding for arts and cultural agencies like the Smithsonian Institution and National Endowment for the Arts. Additionally, appropriations laws for Interior and Related Agencies have funded activities within the Department of Energy in recent years. The FY2006 Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations law consolidated jurisdiction over DOE and EPA under House and Senate Appropriations subcommittees. The FY2007 legislation followed a similar structure with three primary titles providing funding for Interior agencies, EPA, and other programs. The report discusses EPA in Title II and other agencies, programs, and entities in Title III. It does not include FY2007 enacted levels as agencies determine their funding levels. Appropriations represent total funds available, including regular annual and supplemental appropriations. Increases and decreases are calculated based on comparisons between FY2007 funding levels and those requested by the President for FY2007 and appropriated for FY2006. The House Committee on Appropriations is the primary source of funding figures in the report. The funding figures used in the report are primarily sourced from the House Committee on Appropriations, with additional information from the Senate Committee on Appropriations, agency budget justifications, and the Congressional Record. Funding details for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies for FY2007 are outlined in P.L. 110-5, which provides continuing appropriations until September 30, 2007. The law maintains funding at the FY2006 account level, with agencies required to submit allocations below the account level for programs and activities. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees require submissions of fund allocations below the account level within 30 days of enactment. Prior to P.L. 110-5, continuing funds were provided to Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies based on FY2006 or House-passed levels for FY2007. The FY2007 regular annual appropriations bill provided $26.05 billion for these agencies, slightly above the House-passed level. The Senate Appropriations Committee-reported bill for FY2007 proposed changes in funding levels for various agencies. This included decreases for the National Park Service, Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and Environmental Protection Agency, while increases were seen for the Indian Health Service, Bureau of Land Management, and Smithsonian Institution. The Senate Appropriations Committee adopted amendments for the Smithsonian Institution, requiring re-negotiation of OCS oil and gas leases without royalties. The House passed a bill providing $25.94 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies for FY2007, a 2% decrease from the previous year. The House passed a bill with $25.94 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies for FY2007, including amendments to prohibit certain uses of funds and increase funding for specific programs. The House Appropriations Committee adopted amendments to the bill with $25.94 billion for Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies for FY2007. Issues debated included land sales under FLTFA and the sale of National Forest System lands. The President's FY2007 budget assumed opening part of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil and gas exploration. The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is a topic of controversy regarding oil and gas exploration. Funding debates for BIA Schools and IHS Hospitals, as well as Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds, are also contentious issues. The report discusses funding issues for Clean Water and Drinking Water State Revolving Funds, Indian Trust Funds, and Land Acquisition, including the Land and Water Conservation Fund. The curr_chunk discusses various federal programs and issues such as the Land and Water Conservation Fund, Outer Continental Shelf Leasing, Payments in Lieu of Taxes Program, Royalty Relief for oil and gas companies, and the Smithsonian Institution. The curr_chunk discusses funding for the Smithsonian Institution, Superfund cleanup needs, Wildland Fire Fighting funding levels, borrowing funds for wildfires, and environmental analysis challenges. The curr_chunk discusses the Bureau of Land Management's management of public land for various uses, including energy development and fire management on DOI lands. Congressional consideration of the FY2007 Interior appropriations bill and challenges to agency decisions on fuel reduction activities are also mentioned. The Bureau of Land Management manages public land for energy development and wildland fire management on DOI lands. The House approved $1.79 billion and the Senate reported $1.80 billion for BLM in FY2007. The Administration proposed amending the FLTFA to redirect proceeds from land sales to reduce the deficit. Legislation would be required for this change. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees approved funding increases for the Bureau of Land Management in FY2007, with the House allocating $867.7 million and the Senate reporting $876.9 million. Both committees supported the Administration's approach to decrease funds for some programs while increasing funds for others, such as cultural resources. In FY2007, funding for the Bureau of Land Management saw increases for cultural resources and energy/minerals. The House approved $16.6 million for cultural resources, while the Senate committee allocated $18.1 million. Energy and minerals received $134.7 million, with the House supporting $133.0 million and the Senate reporting $138.0 million. The budget aimed to enhance access to energy resources on federal lands and expedite oil shale development. The amendment aims to prevent the sale or slaughter of wild horses and burros by prohibiting funds in the bill from being used for that purpose. Advocates suggest using fertility control as an alternative to reduce herd sizes on federal lands. Opponents argue that the sale authority is necessary due to insufficient efforts in reducing herd sizes through adoptions. In FY2007, the House approved $769.3 million for Wildland Fire Management, a $14.0 million increase from FY2006. The Senate recommended $776.6 million, a $21.4 million increase. Both levels provided funding for fire preparedness and suppression, with increases from the previous year. In FY2007, funding for Wildland Fire Management increased by $26.3 million (11%) from FY2006 to cover the 10-year average cost of fire suppression. The House Appropriations Committee expressed concern about high suppression costs and directed DOI and the FS to review fires with costs over $10.0 million. Reductions were made in other areas, such as a $8.3 million (4%) decrease for hazardous fuels reduction. The Administration and House aimed to eliminate funds for state and local fire assistance, while the Senate included $5.0 million for this purpose, emphasizing the effectiveness of rural and volunteer fire departments. Volunteer fire departments are effective in responding to fires and saving money for the federal government. The FY2006 funding level for state and local fire assistance was $9.9 million. Wildland fire funds are used for fire fighting on Interior Department lands. The House Appropriations Committee expressed concerns about the lack of a comprehensive plan to deal with wildfire management needs. The House Appropriations Committee expressed concerns about the lack of a comprehensive plan to deal with the Nation's wildfire management needs and directed the development of a strategy. Funding allocation for priority projects was questioned, and a report was requested from DOI. Funding levels for BLM construction and Land Acquisition in FY2007 saw varying support and cuts from different entities. The House Appropriations Committee approved a 64% decrease in funding for BLM land acquisition, citing it as a low priority. Funding for BLM acquisitions has decreased steadily from $49.9 million in FY2002 to $8.6 million in FY2006, allocated from the Land and Water Conservation Fund. For more information, visit the Department of the Interior and Bureau of Land Management websites. The President requested $1.29 billion for the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) for FY2007, with the House approving less and the Senate Appropriations Committee approving more. The largest portion of the FWS annual appropriation is for the Resources Management account, which includes programs like the Endangered Species program and Law Enforcement. The President's budget also proposed opening part of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR) to oil and gas exploration. The budget proposed opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR) to oil and gas exploration, with the first lease sale planned for FY2008. It was estimated to generate $4.0 billion in federal revenues over five years. Additionally, there was controversy over funding for the Endangered Species program, with proposed reductions in FY2007. Total funding for the Endangered Species program would decrease slightly, while refuge operations and maintenance funding would see a slight increase. Law Enforcement funding would also see a modest increase. The Administration proposed $7.4 million for the study of avian flu in FY2007, which was approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee. The focus will be on monitoring the virus spread through wild birds, particularly in Alaska, the Pacific Flyway, and Pacific islands. The funds will be used for monitoring, testing, and cooperation with other agencies. The Committee report directed funds for monitoring and testing in Alaska and "vector control efforts in other areas." The House approved $19.8 million for Land Acquisition, a decrease of 29%, earmarking funding for six refuges in the northeast. The Senate approved $42.3 million for acquisitions funded by LWCF. The program focuses on acquiring federal refuge land and related functions. In recent years, funding for traditional land acquisition has decreased. The Administration reserved $13.7 million for specified acquisitions in FY2007, with the House-passed bill allocating a smaller fraction to acquisition. The President's FY2007 budget proposed moving funding from the NMBCF to the MSCF, which was rejected by Congress. The proposed budget for FY2007 included $8.2 million for the MSCF, cutting funding for some species while increasing it for neotropical migratory birds. The House and Senate Appropriations Committee had differing approaches to funding levels. State and Tribal Wildlife Grants also play a role in funding wildlife conservation efforts. State and Tribal Wildlife Grants, created in FY2001, help fund conservation efforts for species of concern to states, territories, and tribes. The program receives support from governments and funds conservation plans and projects. The President proposed an increase to $74.7 million in FY2007, but the House approved a decrease to $50.0 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved maintaining the FY2006 funding level. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved the FY2006 funding level of $50.0 million for State and Tribal Wildlife Grants, setting aside $5.9 million for tribal grants. Both the House and Senate rejected the President's proposal for competitive grants. For more information, visit the Fish and Wildlife Service website. The National Park Service (NPS) oversees 390 diverse park units covering 85 million acres, with a mission to protect and preserve natural and historic areas for public access. The Park System includes various designations like national parks, monuments, and historic sites. The NPS also supports conservation activities outside the Park System through grant programs and partnerships. The Senate Appropriations Committee bill provided $2.23 billion for the NPS, $52.4 million more than the House-passed bill and $72.4 million above the budget request. The NPS budget request aims to cut the federal budget deficit but may impact visitor programs and services due to inflation and rising costs. Amendments adopted by the House increased funding for the Operation of the National Park System by $1.0 million. The House Appropriations Committee increased funding for the National Park System by $1.0 million to enhance security at the Statue of Liberty. The Senate Appropriations Committee bill directed the NPS to maintain the current rule allowing snowmobile use in certain national parks for three more years. The House Appropriations Committee increased funding for the National Park System by $1.0 million to enhance security at the Statue of Liberty. The park operations line-item is the primary source of funding for national parks, covering essential activities, programs, and services. The House-passed bill for FY2007 would extend protection for one additional year. Operations funding is mainly provided to park managers for resource protection, visitor services, facility maintenance, and employee costs. The House Appropriations Committee criticized a Department policy favoring law enforcement rangers over other functions. An NPS "core operations analysis" program aims to reduce fixed costs by 20%-30% without compromising resource protection and visitor hospitality functions. 53 park units have completed studies, with 34 more scheduled to finish by the end of FY2006, and all unit studies are expected to be completed by the end of 2011. The NPS aims to complete all unit studies by the end of 2011. Park advocacy groups seek additional funding for park operations, security, land acquisition, and repairs. The U.S. Park Police provide law enforcement services in urban areas like Washington, DC, New York City, and San Francisco. The U.S. Park Police provide specialized law enforcement services to park units system-wide, with increased funding proposed for security at iconic parks and recruitment of new officers. An internal review in 2004 redefined USPP priorities to focus on protecting iconic park units, patrolling the National Mall, managing special events, conducting criminal investigations, and traffic control. This includes funding for state and local community efforts to preserve natural, cultural, and historic resources. The House agreed not to fund statutory and contractual aid, while the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $5.3 million for this program. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees rejected the Administration's proposal to reduce funding for the heritage partnership program and transfer it to the Historic Preservation Fund. The Senate recommended $14.1 million for the program, above the House allowance and FY2006 levels. They also recommended $234.9 million for NPS construction, including funding for the Harpers Ferry Center not proposed by the NPS. Cuts in construction funds could limit maintenance reduction efforts. The Administration is proposing to hold the line against further backlog accumulation in the NPS maintenance by sustaining the same level of "facility condition index." FY2006 appropriations for the NPS under the Land and Water Conservation Fund were $47.0 million, with funds allocated for land acquisition and state assistance programs. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $63.4 million for NPS land acquisition and state assistance, exceeding the House allowance and request. They also recommended $33.4 million for the federal side of LWCF, with $5.0 million specified for the United Airlines Flight 93 memorial. The request for state assistance funds was limited to $1.6 million for administrative expenses. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $28.4 million for state assistance grants and $1.6 million for administrative expenses. S. 3562 would provide $450 million annually for LWCF state assistance from offshore oil and gas development leases in the Gulf of Mexico, near Florida. The Historic Preservation Fund (HPF) provides grants for restoring historic districts, sites, buildings, and objects significant in American history and culture. The HPF is funded on a 60% federal/40% state matching share basis and includes funding for Save America's Treasures and Preserve America grants. For FY2007, the Senate Appropriations Committee approved $70.7 million for the HPF, $44.5 million below the FY2006 appropriation. Both the House-passed and Senate Appropriations Committee-reported measure would include $35.7 million for grants-in-aid to state historic preservation offices, $3.9 million for Tribal grants, and $1.0 million for preserving and restoring historic buildings and structures on campuses of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). The House and Senate Appropriations Committee disagreed with the Administration's FY2007 request regarding the America's Heritage and Preservation Partnership program and National Heritage areas funding. The NPS supports National Heritage Areas managed by private or state organizations. Save America's Treasures aims to preserve nationally significant intellectual and cultural artifacts and historic structures. Pending legislation (H.R. 3446 and S. 1378) would reauthorize the Historic Preservation Fund through FY2011 and FY2015, making changes to the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation. The US Geological Survey (USGS) is a key science agency providing information on natural hazards, the environment, energy, minerals, water, and biology. It also serves as a mapping agency and monitors water resources. The Administration is focusing on USGS's role in monitoring natural hazards, land cover changes, and mineral resources in FY2007, with a requested budget of $944.8 million. The House and Senate bills would retain funding for Water Resources Research Institutes and mineral resource assessments, but not for the multi-hazards initiative. The Senate committee raised concerns about reprogramming funds for the USGS multi-hazards initiative without specifying funding sources. It consists of three primary programs: Enterprise Information Security and Technology, Enterprise Information Resources, and Federal Geographic Data Coordination. It also prohibits consolidating the MCMC into the National Geospatial Technical Operations Center. The Senate Appropriations Committee bill restricts funds for competitively sourcing functions of the NGTOC without allowing fair competition with other sites. The requested funds for the Landsat Data Continuity Mission, specifically for Landsat 8, would support the establishment of ground systems for data transfer, storage, and accessibility. The Senate Appropriations Committee questions the proposed reduction in force for the program, stating it lacks adequate justification and a resource plan. The Senate Appropriations Committee questions the proposed reduction in force for Geologic Hazards, Resources, and Processes activities, reinstates funding, and expects research and staff levels to remain at the current level. The Administration requested $217.4 million, $17.9 million below the FY2006 enacted level. Despite previous requests for cuts, Congress is considering retaining funding for the program in the FY2007 budget. The Committee strongly disagrees with proposed reduction in program funding and urges Administration not to propose elimination again. House committee disagrees with notion that objective data can be prepared in private sector. Senate Appropriations Committee states reduction has no merit. Administration's request for Water Resources Investigations was $204.0 million, $7.7 million below FY2006 enacted level. House-passed bill included $213.8 million, Senate Appropriations Committee-reported bill contains $216.8 million. USGS support for Water would be discontinued in FY2007 request. The FY2007 budget request would discontinue USGS support for Water Resources Research Institutes due to successful leveraging of funding from non-USGS sources. Congress has provided $6.4 million for the institutes from FY2002 to FY2006. The Administration requested an increase of $2.3 million for the National Streamflow Information Program to continue operating streamgages and increase the number nationwide. The NSIP program aims to increase the number of streamgages by 30 nationwide, providing essential streamflow data for water resource projects. The Biological Research Program, with a proposed budget of $172.6 million, focuses on conservation efforts. The USGS will conduct activities related to Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) under the Terrestrial and Endangered Resources sub-activity, with a requested budget of $3.2 million for FY2007. Sampling for HPAI detection in wild birds began in Alaska in 2005, with a steering committee established in 2006 to coordinate efforts. The USGS will continue sampling birds for HPAI in North America in 2007. The Administration requested $67.4 million for science support, a decrease from the previous year. The House-passed bill would provide $72.4 million for science support. The Administration also requested $95.5 million for facilities maintenance for FY2007. The House-passed bill and the Senate Appropriations Committee-reported bill would provide $95.5 million for Facilities, the same as the requested amount and $0.7 million above the FY2006 enacted level. The Minerals Management Service administers two programs: the Offshore Minerals Management Program and the Minerals Revenue Management Program. OMM administers competitive leasing on Outer Continental Shelf lands and oversees production of offshore oil, gas, and other minerals. MRM collects and disburses bonuses, rents, and royalties paid on federal onshore and OCS leases and Indian mineral leases. The Minerals Management Service collects and disburses revenues from offshore leases, allocating funds to coastal states, the Land and Water Conservation Fund, the Historic Preservation Fund, and the U.S. Treasury. The MMS estimates collecting over $8 billion annually, with fluctuations based on oil and gas prices. Royalties from natural gas production make up 40-45% of receipts, while oil royalties are less than 25%. The FY2007 MMS budget request was $292.3 million, including funds for Oil Spill Research and Royalty and Offshore Minerals Management. The total budget request is 6% lower than the FY2006 enacted amount. The FY2007 budget request for the Minerals Management Service is $163.6 million, a 14% reduction from FY2006. The House recommended $164.4 million, slightly higher than the request, with funding levels approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee. Controversial issues include oil and gas development moratoria in the Outer Continental Shelf. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees retained the moratoria on oil and natural gas leasing in the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) for FY2007. The House approved an amendment for natural gas leasing in OCS moratoria areas, while oil leasing remained prohibited. Legislation (H.R. 4761) passed by the House allowed for natural gas-only drilling in moratoria areas and gave states a larger share of revenue from offshore leases. Royalty relief issues for OCS oil and gas producers have been debated during consideration of FY2007 Interior appropriations. The MMS did not collect royalties on leases awarded in 1998 and 1999 due to the absence of price thresholds in the lease agreements. Producers were allowed to extract oil and gas without paying royalties regardless of the price. The MMS claimed that the omission of price thresholds in the lease agreements was a mistake. The MMS omitted price thresholds in leases awarded in 1998 and 1999, leading to royalty relief for oil and gas producers. An amendment to include price thresholds in leases was proposed in the FY2007 Interior appropriations bill but was removed during House debate. A subsequent amendment prohibited new lease sales to lessees without price thresholds in their leases. Opponents of the amendment argued that companies with valid leases should not be penalized for lacking price thresholds. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved language on price thresholds similar to the House-passed version and required the Secretary of the Interior to renegotiate leases to include price thresholds. The amendment also affirmed the Secretary's authority to adjust royalties based on production prices. Leasing in the Eastern Gulf of Mexico has been controversial, with blocks removed from sale 181 potentially becoming available after 2007. The Senate proposal (S. 2253) aims to lease 3.6 million acres in lease sale 181 area within a year. Coastal state senators are divided on the bill due to concerns about proximity to Florida's coast. Industry groups argue for more Eastern GOM sales, while environmental groups and some officials highlight risks to the environment and local economies. Offshore oil and gas leasing in California remains a contentious issue. The development of federal offshore leases in California was challenged by the State due to inconsistencies with the coastal zone management plan. The court struck down lease suspensions granted by MMS, leading to appeals by the Bush Administration. The Ninth Circuit upheld the District Court decision, and the Department of the Interior is working with lessees to resolve the issue. A breach-of-contract lawsuit was filed against MMS by nine oil companies seeking compensation for undeveloped leases in offshore California. The U.S. Federal Court of Claims determined that the government breached its contract with the lessees, ordering repayment of $1.1 billion. Final judgment is deferred pending resolution of additional claims. For more information on the Minerals Management Service, visit http://www.mms.gov. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act (SMCRA) established regulations for coal mining reclamation, including the creation of an Abandoned Mine Lands (AML) fund funded by coal production fees. States and tribes develop their own regulatory programs based on federal standards. Fee collections are divided into federal and state shares, with grants awarded based on a distribution formula. Some states have requested increased AML appropriations in recent years. States have pushed for increased AML appropriations due to unappropriated balances exceeding $1 billion. Western states feel they are unfairly burdened as coal production shifts westward. The Administration proposed restructuring the program in FY2005 and FY2006, but it was not widely supported. Other reauthorization proposals have been introduced in Congress. The reauthorization of AML fee collection program has faced challenges in Congress, leading to short-term extensions. The FY2007 request seeks an interim extension while working towards a long-term resolution. The House Appropriations Committee supports an interim extension but emphasizes the need for a permanent solution. The Administration requested $185.9 million for FY2007, a slight increase from the previous year. The Administration requested $298.1 million for the Office of Surface Mining (OSM) for FY2007, an increase of $4.0 million from the previous year. This includes $112.2 million for regulation and technology programs, with a focus on environmental protection. Additionally, $1.5 million was requested for minimum program states with significant Abandoned Mine Land (AML) problems. The Senate Appropriations Committee and the House supported the Administration's funding levels for FY2007. The Senate Appropriations Committee and the House have limited funding for minimum program states to $1.5 million annually since FY1996. The Rural Abandoned Mine Program (RAMP) has not received funds since FY1996, with a $361 million balance transferred to the federal share of AML collections in FY2006. The FY2007 Administration request recommended continuing this practice, with the House including language to transfer the RAMP balance to the federal share fund. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) provides various services to federally-recognized tribes and their members, including government operations, law enforcement, education, and economic development. BIA's FY2006 direct appropriations were $2.27 billion, with a proposed decrease to $2.22 billion for FY2007. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) budget for FY2007 was proposed at $2.22 billion, with the House approving $2.23 billion and the Senate Appropriations Committee recommending $2.27 billion. Key issues for the BIA include reorganization and trust asset management functions. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) budget for FY2007 includes reorganization of the Bureau, trust asset management functions, and issues in BIA education programs. The budget presentation has been restructured to group programs with the same function under the same budget activity, such as education. Tribal Priority Allocations (TPA) budget activity is significant for tribes as it covers basic tribal services and allows tribes to prioritize programs without prior BIA approval. The BIA's FY2007 budget includes Tribal Priority Allocations (TPA) funding of $754.1 million, with potential overlap from FY2006. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees praised the new budget structure but requested reports on various aspects of BIA management. Interior Secretary Norton initiated a reorganization of the BIA, AS-IA, and the Office of Special Trustee for American Indians in April 2003. The reorganization of the BIA, AS-IA, and the Office of Special Trustee for American Indians was initiated in April 2003 due to issues related to trust funds and assets management. The BIA has historically managed trust funds and assets for Indian tribes and individuals, including 45 million acres of tribal trust land and 10 million acres of individual Indian trust land. Trust assets management involves real estate services, transactions processing, surveys, appraisals, probate functions, and land title records activities. The BIA has faced criticism for mismanaging Indian trust funds and assets, leading to trust reform in 1994 and a court case in 1996. The Office of Special Trustee was created in 1994 to oversee trust management reform. In 1996, trust fund management was transferred to the OST from the BIA. Efforts at trust management reform in the 1990s were unsuccessful, leading to a management consultant firm being contracted in 2001 for recommendations on improvements. The Department of Interior announced a reorganization in 2002 for trust management improvement after consultation with Indian tribes. The reorganization involves BIA, AS-IA, and OST focusing on trust management structures and functions, adding trust officers to oversee trust management at regional and agency levels.
